date:
date Input Type

The <input type="date"> is used for input fields that should contain date.

Depending on the browser support, a date picker can show up in the input field.

You can also add the min and max attributes to add restrictions to dates.

Example:

<!DOCTYPE html>

<html>

<head>

<title>date input type</title>

</head>

<body>

<form>

Birthday:

<input type="date" name="birthday" min="2000-01-01" max="2019-03-15" >

</form>

</body>

</html>
month:
month Input Type

The <input type="month"> allow users to select a month and year in the format yyyy-mm, such as 2019-04, where 04 corresponds to the fourth week of year 2019.

Depending on the browser support, a date picker can show up in the input field.

Example:

<!DOCTYPE html>

<html>

<head>

<title>month input type</title>

</head>

<body>

<form>

Birthday (month and year):

<input type="month" name="birthdaymonth">

</form>

</body>

</html>
week:
week Input Type

The <input type="week"> allows users to select a week and year in the format yyyy-Wnn, for example 2019-W05, where 05 is the fifth week in year 2019.

Depending onthe browser support, a date picker can show up in the input field.

Example:

<!DOCTYPE html>

<html>

<head>

<title>week input type</title>

</head>

<body>

<form>

Select a week:

<input type="week" name="yourweek">

</form>

</body>

</html>
time:
time Input Type

The <input type="time"> allows users to select a time (no time zone).

The user can enter an hour, minute, seconds and fraction of a second.

The HTML5 specification indicates thata time must have two digits for hour, followed by a colon (:) and two digits representing the minute. Optionally, you can also include a colon followed by two digits representing the seconds and a period followed by one or more digits representing a fraction of a second.

Depending onthe browser support, a date picker can show up in the input field.

Example:

<!DOCTYPE html>

<html>

<head>

<title>time input type</title>

</head>

<body>

<form>

Select a time:

<input type="time" name="yourtime">

</form>

</body>

</html>
email:
email Input Type

The <input type="email"> is used for input fields that should contain an e-mail address. Ther user can enter a list of emails separated by commas (if the multiple attribute is specified).

HTML5 does not check whether an e-mail address entered by the user exists, but rather it just validates that the e-mail address is in the proper format.

Depending on browser support, the e-mail address can be automatically validated when submitted.

Some smartphones recognize the email type, and add ".com" to the keyboard to match email input.

Example:

<!DOCTYPE html>

<html>

<head>

<title>email Input Typ</title>

</head>

<body>

<form>

Select a time:

<input type="email" name="youremail">

</form>

</body>

</html>
number:
number Input Type

The <input type="number"> defines a numeric input field. It enables the user to enter a numerical value. Mobile browsers typically display a numeric keypad for this input type

You can also set restrictions on what numbers are accepted, and how they are incremented.

The min attribute sets the minimum valid number, and the max attribute sets the maximum valid number. The step attribute determines the increment in which the numbers increase. The value attribute sets the initial value displayed in the form.

The following example displays a numeric input field, where you can enter an even value between 2 and 10, and the initial value is 6:

Example:

<!DOCTYPE html>

<html>

<head>

<title>number Input Typ</title>

</head>

<body>

<form>

Select a time:

<input type="number" name="pickanumber" min="0" max="10" step="2" value="6">

</form>

</body>

</html>
range:
range Input Type

The <input type="range"> defines a control for entering a number whose exact value is not important (like a slider control). The default range is 0 to 100.

You can also set restrictions on what numbers are accepted, and how they are incremented.

The min attribute sets the minimum valid number, and the max attribute sets the maximum valid number. The step attribute determines the increment in which the numbers increase. The value attribute sets the initial value desplayed in the form.

The range input type is inherently self-validating when it is rendered by the browser as a slider control, because the user is unable to move the slider outside the bounds of the minimum or maximum values.

The following example displays a numeric input field, where you can enter an even value between 2 and 10, and the initial value is 6:

Example:

<!DOCTYPE html>

<html>

<head>

<title>range Input Typ</title>

</head>

<body>

<form>

Select a time:

<input type="range" name="pickanumber" min="0" max="10" step="2" value="6">

</form>

</body>

</html>
tel:
tel Input Type

The <input type="tel"> is used for input fields that should contain a telephone number.

Mobile browsers tipycally display a keypad specific to entering phone numbers for this input type.

The tel type is currently only supported in Safari 8. And all other browsers render the tel input type as a text field.

Since phone numbers length vary greatlty based on the location, it is recommended to use the pattern attribute to ensure that the user enters a phone number in a proper format. This pattern attribute uses a regular expession to determine whether the number is in the correct format.

Example:

<!DOCTYPE html>

<html>

<head>

<title>tel Input Typ</title>

</head>

<body>

<form>

Select a time:

<input type="tel" name="phonenumber" pattern="\(\d{3} + \d{3}-\d{4}">

</form>

</body>

</html>
url:
url Input Type

The <input type="url"> is used for input fields that should contain a URL address.

Depending on browser support, the url field can be automatically validated when submitted.

Some smartphones recognize the url type, and adds ".com" to the keyboard to match url input.

The element is rendered as a text field, the proper format is http://www.domain.com .

HTML5 does not check whether the URL entered is valid; rather it validates that the URL entered is in the proper format.

Example:

<!DOCTYPE html>

<html>

<head>

<title>url Input Typ</title>

</head>

<body>

<form>

Select a time:

<input type="url" name="mywebsite">

</form>

</body>

</html>
